user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_create:
```c
struct MemoryPool *
MHD_pool_create (size_t max)
{
  struct MemoryPool *pool;
  size_t alloc_size;

  mhd_assert (max > 0);
  alloc_size = 0;
  pool = malloc (sizeof (struct MemoryPool));
  if (NULL == pool)
    return NULL;
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) || defined(_WIN32)
  if ( (max <= 32 * 1024) ||
       (max < MHD_sys_page_size_ * 4 / 3) )
  {
    pool->memory = MAP_FAILED;
  }
  else
  {
    /* Round up allocation to page granularity. */
    alloc_size = max + MHD_sys_page_size_ - 1;
    alloc_size -= alloc_size % MHD_sys_page_size_;
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && ! defined(_WIN32)
    pool->memory = mmap (NULL,
                         alloc_size,
                         PROT_READ | PROT_WRITE,
                         MAP_PRIVATE | MAP_ANONYMOUS,
                         -1,
                         0);
#elif defined(_WIN32)
    pool->memory = VirtualAlloc (NULL,
                                 alloc_size,
                                 MEM_COMMIT | MEM_RESERVE,
                                 PAGE_READWRITE);
#endif /* _WIN32 */
  }
#else  /* ! _WIN32 && ! MAP_ANONYMOUS */
  pool->memory = MAP_FAILED;
#endif /* ! _WIN32 && ! MAP_ANONYMOUS */
  if (MAP_FAILED == pool->memory)
  {
    alloc_size = ROUND_TO_ALIGN (max);
    pool->memory = malloc (alloc_size);
    if (NULL == pool->memory)
    {
      free (pool);
      return NULL;
    }
    pool->is_mmap = false;
  }
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) || defined(_WIN32)
  else
  {
    pool->is_mmap = true;
  }
#endif /* _WIN32 || MAP_ANONYMOUS */
  mhd_assert (0 == (((uintptr_t) pool->memory) % ALIGN_SIZE));
  pool->pos = 0;
  pool->end = alloc_size;
  pool->size = alloc_size;
  mhd_assert (0 < alloc_size);
  _MHD_POISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
  return pool;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_pool_create:
struct MemoryPool
{

  /**
   * Pointer to the pool's memory
   */
  uint8_t *memory;

  /**
   * Size of the pool.
   */
  size_t size;

  /**
   * Offset of the first unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t pos;

  /**
   * Offset of the byte after the last unallocated byte.
   */
  size_t end;

  /**
   * 'false' if pool was malloc'ed, 'true' if mmapped (VirtualAlloc'ed for W32).
   */
  bool is_mmap;
}
...
#define _MHD_POISON_MEMORY(pointer, size) (void)0
...
#define ROUND_TO_ALIGN(n) (((n)+(ALIGN_SIZE-1))/(ALIGN_SIZE)*(ALIGN_SIZE))
...
#define ALIGN_SIZE (2*sizeof(void*))
...
static size_t MHD_sys_page_size_ = (size_t)
#if defined(MHD_USE_PAGESIZE_MACRO_STATIC)
                                   PAGESIZE;
#elif defined(MHD_USE_PAGE_SIZE_MACRO_STATIC)
                                   PAGE_SIZE;
#else  /* ! MHD_USE_PAGE_SIZE_MACRO_STATIC */
                                   _MHD_FALLBACK_PAGE_SIZE
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments require investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 because all pointers in the provided code are used in ways that require mutable (non-const) access:

- pool (struct MemoryPool *pool): the function allocates and then writes multiple mutable fields (memory, pos, end, size, is_mmap). The object pointed to must be modifiable, so a const-qualified pointer would be inappropriate.

- pool->memory (uint8_t *memory): this pointer refers to the pool storage that will be used for allocations and is (potentially) written to (e.g. by allocation consumers and by the _MHD_POISON_MEMORY macro). That storage must be mutable, so the pointer should not be to const-qualified data.

- The function return type (struct MemoryPool *): callers are expected to modify the returned pool (manage allocations, free, etc.), so returning a pointer-to-const would be incorrect.

- Assignments from mmap/VirtualAlloc/malloc and use of MAP_FAILED/NULL: these simply initialize pool->memory with raw, mutable storage pointers (or MAP_FAILED sentinel). They do not indicate that the pointed-to storage is immutable.

Because each pointer is either used to modify the pointed-to object or represents ownership of mutable storage, making them point to const-qualified types would be inappropriate; therefore there are no fragments that violate or likely violate Rule 8.13 in this function.
